abstract.p: Maureen Richards letter agrees with Francine Prose's August 6 article on book reviewers (S)

block.p: Hurrah for Francine Prose (''Giveaways,'' Aug. 6). I have adapted to the sorry state of book ''reviews'' (80 to 90 percent plot summaries) by glancing at the opening paragraph, then dashing to the reviewer's conclusion. Even the hint of a surprise twist can diminish the reader's pleasure. I am sure I am not the only amateur detective to guess Coleman's secret in Philip Roth's novel ''The Human Stain.''
The real mystery of Roth's book is: How did he create this wondrous piece of art? If this is not the subject of the review, the reviewer should be writing for Cliffs Notes.
